critique: The document centralizes power in the executive branch, specifically the Director of the Office of Emergency Planning, regarding telecommunications management and radio frequency assignments. This includes the authority to amend, modify, or revoke frequency assignments and authorize foreign governments to construct and operate radio stations. The order emphasizes federal control over telecommunications, potentially impacting state and local agencies. There is a security focus implied by centralizing control over radio frequencies, potentially at the expense of some liberties. The document does not directly address economic regulation, immigration, ideological tilt, or social inclusion.
